title: Jeremiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 42 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 42.

questions.question: Who came near to Jeremiah to ask for prayer in Jeremiah 42:1?
options: Johanan the son of Kareah and captains of the forces
King of Babylon
Priests and Levites
Prophets of Baal
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah and captains of the forces
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:1 states that the captains of the forces, Johanan the son of Kareah, Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah, and all the people came near to Jeremiah.

questions.question: What did the people ask Jeremiah to do for them in Jeremiah 42:2?
options: Pray to the LORD their God for the remnant
Fight against Babylon
Build a new city
Offer sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Pray to the LORD their God for the remnant
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:2 records the people beseeching Jeremiah to pray for them to the LORD for all the remnant left.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42:3, what did the people want the LORD to show them?
options: The way wherein they may walk and the thing they may do
The location of treasure
The future kings of Israel
How to build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: The way wherein they may walk and the thing they may do
questions.explanation: The people asked that the LORD may show them the way to walk and what to do, as stated in Jeremiah 42:3.

questions.question: How long did Jeremiah wait before receiving the word of the LORD in Jeremiah 42:7?
options: Ten days
One day
Seven days
Thirty days
questions.correctAnswer: Ten days
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:7 says that after ten days the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah.

questions.question: What did the LORD promise if the people chose to abide in the land according to Jeremiah 42:10?
options: He will build and plant them, not pull them down or pluck them up
He will send a flood
He will exile them to Babylon
He will bring famine
questions.correctAnswer: He will build and plant them, not pull them down or pluck them up
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 promises that if they remain in the land, the LORD will build and plant them and will not uproot them.

questions.question: Who did the LORD say not to fear in Jeremiah 42:11?
options: The king of Babylon
The Egyptians
The Philistines
The Assyrians
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:11 instructs them not to fear the king of Babylon because the LORD is with them to save and deliver.

questions.question: What did the people plan to do instead of obeying the voice of the LORD, as described in Jeremiah 42:14?
options: Go into the land of Egypt where there is no war or hunger
Build a new temple in Jerusalem
Fight against Babylon
Return to their own land freely
questions.correctAnswer: Go into the land of Egypt where there is no war or hunger
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:14 explains their plan to go into Egypt to avoid war and hunger.

questions.question: What consequence did the LORD warn would happen to those who go into Egypt in Jeremiah 42:16?
options: They will be overtaken by the sword and famine and die there
They will find peace and safety
They will become kings
They will prosper and multiply
questions.correctAnswer: They will be overtaken by the sword and famine and die there
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:16 warns that the sword and famine will overtake them in Egypt and they will die there.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42:19, what did the LORD say to the remnant of Judah?
options: Go not into Egypt
Build cities in Egypt
Make peace with Egypt
Send gifts to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Go not into Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:19 clearly states the LORD's command to the remnant of Judah not to go into Egypt.

questions.question: What did Jeremiah accuse the people of doing in their hearts in Jeremiah 42:20?
options: Dissembling when they sent him to pray
Being completely honest
Building altars
Obeying the LORD fully
questions.correctAnswer: Dissembling when they sent him to pray
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:20 states that they dissembled in their hearts when they sent him to pray for them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah promised to keep nothing back from the people regarding the LORD’s answer (Jeremiah 42:4).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:4 confirms Jeremiah would declare the LORD’s answer without withholding anything.

questions.question: True or False: The people said they would only obey the LORD's voice if the message was good (Jeremiah 42:6).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:6 shows they vowed to obey whether the LORD's message was good or evil.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah warned that those who disobey would die by sword, famine, and pestilence where they desire to go (Jeremiah 42:22).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:22 clearly states that disobedient ones will die by sword, famine, and pestilence where they want to sojourn.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 42:5: 'The LORD be a true and faithful _______ between us.'
options: witness
king
prophet
judge
questions.correctAnswer: witness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:5 uses the phrase 'The LORD be a true and faithful witness between us.'

questions.question: Complete the promise from Jeremiah 42:12: 'And I will shew mercies unto you, that he may have mercy upon you, and cause you to ________ to your own land.'
options: return
fear
flee
prosper
questions.correctAnswer: return
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:12 promises mercy so that they may return to their own land.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 42 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear of external threats. Based on Jeremiah 42, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: God promises to be with us and deliver us, so we should not fear enemies.
We must rely on our own strength to overcome threats.
Ignoring the threat is the best way to find peace.
We should flee to foreign lands to avoid danger.
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to be with us and deliver us, so we should not fear enemies.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:11 teaches us not to fear the king of Babylon because God is with His people to save and deliver them. This encourages believers to trust in God's protection rather than fear.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42, how should believers respond to God's instructions, even if the outcome might be difficult?
options: Obey God's voice whether it is good or evil.
Only obey when it benefits us.
Ignore God's instructions if they seem harsh.
Wait and see what others do first.
questions.correctAnswer: Obey God's voice whether it is good or evil.
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 show that the people committed to obeying God's voice regardless of good or evil, trusting that obedience leads to well-being. This teaches faithfulness and submission to God's will.

questions.question: When faced with a difficult decision, what does Jeremiah 42 teach us about seeking guidance from God?
options: We should pray and wait patiently for God's answer before acting.
We should act quickly without consulting God.
We should rely on popular opinion.
We should avoid making decisions altogether.
questions.correctAnswer: We should pray and wait patiently for God's answer before acting.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:4-7 describes how Jeremiah prayed to God for guidance and waited ten days before receiving God's word. This shows the importance of patient prayer and waiting for divine direction.

questions.question: What warning does Jeremiah 42 give about relying on a place of perceived safety rather than God's guidance?
options: Going to Egypt for safety will lead to death by sword, famine, and pestilence.
Egypt is a guaranteed safe refuge.
Fleeing to another land is always God's will.
Ignoring God's commands ensures peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Going to Egypt for safety will lead to death by sword, famine, and pestilence.
questions.explanation: Verses 15-17 warn that those who disobey God and go to Egypt will face the very dangers they hope to avoid, teaching reliance on God over worldly refuges.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 42 emphasize the importance of honesty and integrity in our relationship with God?
options: God knows if our hearts are sincere when we seek Him.
Pretending to seek God is acceptable if it comforts us.
We can deceive God by our words.
Actions don’t matter if we pray.
questions.correctAnswer: God knows if our hearts are sincere when we seek Him.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:20 reveals that the people dissembled in their hearts despite their words, indicating that honesty and integrity before God are essential for true obedience.

questions.question: Based on Jeremiah 42, what can we learn about God's attitude toward repentance and restoration?
options: God repents of the evil He has done and promises to build and plant those who obey Him.
God is unwilling to forgive past sins.
God ignores those who have sinned.
God punishes without any hope for restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: God repents of the evil He has done and promises to build and plant those who obey Him.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 shows God’s mercy and willingness to restore His people if they remain obedient, illustrating His gracious nature and desire for repentance.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 42 teach about trusting God's promises during times of trial and uncertainty?
options: Trusting God’s promises brings peace even amid threats and famine.
God’s promises are only for times of prosperity.
We should rely on our own plans instead of God’s promises.
Promises from God are unreliable.
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God’s promises brings peace even amid threats and famine.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:12 assures that God will show mercy and cause return to their land, teaching believers to trust God’s faithfulness despite hardships.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 42 shows that God’s word through His prophet must be fully obeyed to experience His blessing and protection.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:21-22 indicates that disobedience to God's word results in death and calamity, highlighting the necessity of full obedience for God’s blessing.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 42 encourages believers to seek foreign lands as a solution to avoid conflict and hardship.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:13-17 warns against going to Egypt to escape trouble, showing that fleeing from God’s will leads to judgment and suffering rather than peace.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to disobey God's clear instructions for easier paths. What principle from Jeremiah 42 would you share about obedience?
options: Obedience to God’s voice leads to well-being even if it seems hard.
Obedience is optional based on convenience.
God will bless disobedience if intentions are good.
Choosing the easiest path is always best.
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s voice leads to well-being even if it seems hard.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:6 emphasizes that obeying God’s voice leads to good outcomes and well-being, teaching practical faith and trust in God’s guidance even in difficulty.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 42 instruct believers to handle supplication and prayer in times of crisis?
options: Approach God with sincere prayer and ask for His guidance.
Pray only when things are going well.
Rely on rituals without heartfelt prayer.
Avoid prayer and seek human advice first.
questions.correctAnswer: Approach God with sincere prayer and ask for His guidance.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:2-4 shows the people asking Jeremiah to pray for them and seek God's direction, highlighting the importance of sincere prayer during crises.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 42 teaches that those who _______ God's voice and go to Egypt will face death by sword, famine, and pestilence.
options: disobey
obey
ignore
pray
questions.correctAnswer: disobey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:17 clearly states that those who set their faces to go to Egypt and disobey God's voice will die by sword, famine, and pestilence, showing the consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42, what role does Jeremiah play as a prophet in relation to the people’s requests?
options: He faithfully delivers God's answers without withholding anything.
He gives his own opinions instead of God's word.
He refuses to speak to the people.
He only tells them what they want to hear.
questions.correctAnswer: He faithfully delivers God's answers without withholding anything.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:4 shows Jeremiah promising to declare all that God answers without keeping anything back, demonstrating prophetic integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 42 teach about God's anger and its consequences on those who disobey?
options: God’s anger will be poured out on those who disobey, leading to judgment and curse.
God ignores disobedience without consequences.
God’s anger only affects the wicked in distant lands.
God’s anger is temporary and has no real effect.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anger will be poured out on those who disobey, leading to judgment and curse.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:18 explains that God's fury will be poured out on those who disobey and enter Egypt, resulting in them becoming a curse and reproach, highlighting the seriousness of disobedience.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 42 encourage believers to maintain humility and contentment in their current circumstances?
options: By trusting God's promise to build and plant them if they dwell where He commands.
By always seeking to escape difficulties.
By comparing themselves to others in better situations.
By demanding quick relief from hardships.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God's promise to build and plant them if they dwell where He commands.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 encourages believers to remain in the land God gives and trust His promise to build and plant them, fostering humility and contentment through obedience.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 42.

questions.question: Who approached Jeremiah to seek guidance and prayer for the remnant in Jeremiah 42?
options: Johanan the son of Kareah and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah
The priests and Levites only
The elders of Jerusalem alone
The Babylonian officials
questions.correctAnswer: Johanan the son of Kareah and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:1-2 identifies Johanan the son of Kareah and Jezaniah the son of Hoshaiah, along with the captains and all the people, as the ones who came near to Jeremiah seeking prayer and guidance.

questions.question: What did the people request Jeremiah to do on their behalf before the LORD?
options: Pray for them to know the way they should walk
Offer sacrifices to the LORD in the temple
Lead them into battle against Babylon
Write a new covenant for them
questions.correctAnswer: Pray for them to know the way they should walk
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:3 states that the people asked Jeremiah to pray to the LORD that He may show them the way in which they should walk and the thing they should do.

questions.question: What solemn oath did the people make to Jeremiah regarding the LORD's instructions?
options: They would obey whatever the LORD commands through Jeremiah, whether good or evil
They would only obey if the LORD commanded prosperity
They would consult the priests before obeying
They would obey only if the instructions were to go to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They would obey whatever the LORD commands through Jeremiah, whether good or evil
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 42:5-6, the people swear that the LORD be a true witness if they do not obey all that the LORD will send through Jeremiah, whether it is good or evil.

questions.question: After how many days did Jeremiah receive the word of the LORD following the people's request?
options: Ten days
Seven days
Three days
Fifteen days
questions.correctAnswer: Ten days
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:7 specifies that after ten days, the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah.

questions.question: What assurance did the LORD give to the remnant if they chose to remain in the land?
options: He would build and plant them, not pull them down or uproot them
He would send them into exile in Babylon
He would allow them to conquer Egypt
He would give them riches and fame
questions.correctAnswer: He would build and plant them, not pull them down or uproot them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 promises that if they stay in the land, the LORD will build and plant them and repent of the evil He has done, indicating restoration rather than destruction.

questions.question: What reason does the LORD give for telling the remnant not to fear the king of Babylon?
options: Because He is with them to save and deliver them from Babylon's hand
Because Babylon will soon be destroyed by Egypt
Because they will form an alliance with Babylon
Because they will flee to the mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Because He is with them to save and deliver them from Babylon's hand
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:11 states that the LORD tells them not to fear the king of Babylon because He is with them to save and deliver them from his hand.

questions.question: If the remnant refuses to dwell in the land and instead chooses Egypt, what does the LORD warn will happen to them there?
options: They will die by sword, famine, and pestilence
They will live in peace and prosperity
They will be welcomed as honored guests
They will become rulers over Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: They will die by sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:16-17 clearly warns that those who go to Egypt to sojourn will face death by sword, famine, and pestilence and none will escape.

questions.question: What literary device is used in Jeremiah 42:10 where God contrasts building and planting with pulling down and uprooting?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Metaphor
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses synonymous parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, contrasting positive actions (build, plant) with negative ones (pull down, pluck up) to emphasize restoration versus destruction.

questions.question: True or False: The people fully obeyed the voice of the LORD after hearing Jeremiah's prophecy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:21 states that despite the LORD's message, the people did not obey the voice of the LORD or the instructions given through Jeremiah.

questions.question: What is the significance of the LORD saying He 'repents' of the evil done to the remnant if they stay in the land?
options: It reflects a Hebrew anthropopathism indicating God's change in relational stance
It means God made a mistake and regrets it
It implies God's weakness before human decisions
It suggests that God will forget His covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a Hebrew anthropopathism indicating God's change in relational stance
questions.explanation: The use of 'repent' (Hebrew: nacham) here is a common anthropopathism where God expresses a change in His dealings with people without implying error, reflecting His mercy and covenant faithfulness (Jeremiah 42:10).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 42:19-20 indicate the people's duplicity in their request to Jeremiah?
options: They dissembled in their hearts, pretending to seek the LORD's will but intending to disobey
They openly declared their rejection of God's word
They refused to listen to Jeremiah at all
They sought an alliance with Babylon secretly
questions.correctAnswer: They dissembled in their hearts, pretending to seek the LORD's will but intending to disobey
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:20 reveals the people's hypocrisy—they told Jeremiah to ask the LORD and declare all His words, but in their hearts, they planned not to obey.

questions.question: Which theme in Jeremiah 42 foreshadows later Israelite exile and judgment themes found in the book of Ezekiel?
options: The warning against fleeing to Egypt and the consequences of disobedience
The promise of immediate military victory
The construction of a new temple
The appointment of a new king
questions.correctAnswer: The warning against fleeing to Egypt and the consequences of disobedience
questions.explanation: The motif of disobedience leading to exile and judgment, especially the warning not to flee to Egypt, is echoed in Ezekiel’s prophecies relating to Israel's fate (cf. Ezekiel 17:15-16). Jeremiah 42 develops this theme.

questions.question: In the historical and cultural context of Jeremiah 42, what does the land symbolize for the remnant of Judah?
options: Covenantal blessing and God's presence
A place of exile and punishment
An uninhabited wilderness
A foreign territory under Egyptian control
questions.correctAnswer: Covenantal blessing and God's presence
questions.explanation: The land of Judah represents God's covenantal promise and presence; staying in the land symbolizes faithfulness and receiving God's mercy, while fleeing to Egypt symbolizes disobedience and loss of blessing (Jeremiah 42:10-12).

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'LORD of hosts' in Jeremiah 42:15 in the context of divine authority?
options: It emphasizes God's supreme power over heavenly armies and earthly nations
It refers only to God's mercy
It is a title used exclusively for the king of Judah
It indicates a local deity of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's supreme power over heavenly armies and earthly nations
questions.explanation: The title 'LORD of hosts' (YHWH Sabaoth) asserts God's sovereign authority over celestial armies and nations, underscoring His power to enact judgment and salvation (Jeremiah 42:15).

questions.question: Jeremiah 42:18 describes the remnant becoming an 'execration, an astonishment, a curse, and a reproach' upon entering Egypt. What literary technique does this phrase demonstrate?
options: Accumulation or gradatio
Simile
Hyperbole
Paradox
questions.correctAnswer: Accumulation or gradatio
questions.explanation: The phrase uses accumulation or gradatio — a rhetorical device piling up terms with similar negative meanings to intensify the condemnation of the remnant’s fate (Jeremiah 42:18).

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 42 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 42 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial request made by the remnant of Judah to Jeremiah in Jeremiah 42?
options: To pray to the LORD for guidance
To lead them into battle against Babylon
To curse their enemies
To give them wealth and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: To pray to the LORD for guidance
questions.explanation: In Jeremiah 42:2-3, the remnant beseeches Jeremiah to pray to the LORD to show them the way to walk and the thing they should do. This reflects a biblical theme of seeking God's guidance (Proverbs 3:5-6, Psalm 25:4-5, James 1:5, Isaiah 30:21).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42, what was the people's promise to the LORD through Jeremiah's mediation?
options: To obey whatever the LORD commands, whether good or evil
To fight to the death against Babylon
To flee to Egypt immediately
To build a new temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To obey whatever the LORD commands, whether good or evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:5-6 records the people's promise to obey all that the LORD commands through Jeremiah, whether it be good or evil. This echoes biblical teachings on submission to God's sovereign will (Romans 8:28, Job 1:21, 1 Samuel 3:18, Daniel 3:17-18).

questions.question: What assurance did the LORD give to the remnant if they remained in the land according to Jeremiah 42?
options: He would build and plant them and not pluck them up
They would conquer their enemies by force
They would receive immediate wealth
They would be exempt from all suffering
questions.correctAnswer: He would build and plant them and not pluck them up
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 assures that if they remain, God will build and plant them and not uproot them, signifying God's faithfulness and covenantal mercy (Isaiah 54:17, Ezekiel 36:8-10, Psalm 1:3, Jeremiah 31:28).

questions.question: What reason did the LORD give for the remnant not to fear the king of Babylon?
options: Because the LORD Himself would save and deliver them
Because Babylon had been defeated by Egypt
Because they would be hidden in secret caves
Because the king of Babylon had changed his mind
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD Himself would save and deliver them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:11 states God’s promise to save and deliver them from the king of Babylon, revealing God's protective and salvific nature (Exodus 14:13-14, Psalm 34:17, Isaiah 43:1-2, Romans 8:31).

questions.question: What consequence did God declare would come upon the remnant if they disobeyed and went into Egypt?
options: They would die by sword, famine, and pestilence in Egypt
They would find peace and prosperity
They would be crowned kings
They would build a great temple
questions.correctAnswer: They would die by sword, famine, and pestilence in Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:16-17 warns that disobedience by going to Egypt would result in death by sword, famine, and pestilence, reinforcing God's justice and consequences for rebellion (Deuteronomy 28:64-67, 2 Chronicles 36:16, Ezekiel 14:21, Hebrews 12:6).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah was instructed to tell the people that if they would still abide in this land, then God would _____ and not pull them down.
options: build them
curse them
abandon them
ignore them
questions.correctAnswer: build them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 says God will 'build you, and not pull you down,' showing His desire to restore and preserve His people, consistent with God's covenantal faithfulness (Psalm 127:1, Isaiah 58:12, Ezekiel 37:26-28, 1 Peter 2:5).

questions.question: What did the remnant claim about their numbers when they came to Jeremiah?
options: They were left but a few of many
They were the strongest army in the land
They had the most wealth
They were the descendants of kings
questions.correctAnswer: They were left but a few of many
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:2 says they were 'left but a few of many,' highlighting their humility and recognition of their diminished state, a common biblical theme of God's people in exile (Psalm 107:10-16, Isaiah 10:20-22, Ezekiel 6:8, Romans 9:27).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 42, what did the LORD say about His attitude toward the evil He had done unto the people if they stayed?
options: He would repent of the evil
He would increase the punishment
He would remain indifferent
He would hide His face
questions.correctAnswer: He would repent of the evil
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:10 mentions God repents of the evil done if they remain, showing His mercy and willingness to forgive, echoing God's compassionate character (Joel 2:13, 2 Chronicles 7:14, Jonah 3:10, Lamentations 3:22-23).

questions.question: What did God say would happen to those who set their faces to go into Egypt, according to Jeremiah 42?
options: They would become an execration, astonishment, curse, and reproach
They would be welcomed with open arms
They would become kings of Egypt
They would prosper and multiply
questions.correctAnswer: They would become an execration, astonishment, curse, and reproach
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:18 declares God would pour out His fury, making them a curse and reproach, illustrating the severity of disobedience and God's righteous wrath (Deuteronomy 28:20, Ezekiel 5:11, Nahum 1:2, Romans 1:18).

questions.question: What was Jeremiah's role after receiving the word of the LORD in Jeremiah 42?
options: To declare all that the LORD would say to the people without hiding anything
To lead the people into Egypt
To organize a military defense
To write a new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: To declare all that the LORD would say to the people without hiding anything
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:4 shows Jeremiah's commitment to faithfully declare God's message fully, reflecting the prophetic office's calling (Deuteronomy 18:18-19, Ezekiel 2:7, Amos 3:7, Revelation 22:18-19).

questions.question: What did the people swear as a witness between themselves and Jeremiah concerning obedience?
options: The LORD would be a true and faithful witness
The king of Babylon would protect them
They would not listen to any prophet
They would build their own gods
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD would be a true and faithful witness
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:5 records their oath invoking the LORD as a true and faithful witness, underscoring the seriousness of covenant vows (Genesis 31:50, Psalm 89:34, Hebrews 6:17-18, Matthew 5:33-37).

questions.question: What specific phrase describes the people's desire regarding Egypt in Jeremiah 42?
options: To dwell there where there is no war or famine
To conquer Egypt by force
To build a temple in Egypt
To send offerings to Egypt's gods
questions.correctAnswer: To dwell there where there is no war or famine
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:14 records their desire to dwell in Egypt where they perceive safety from war and famine, revealing a common human desire to escape suffering but neglecting obedience to God (Exodus 1:8-10, Psalm 46:1-3, Isaiah 31:1, Matthew 6:33).

questions.question: What key theological theme is emphasized by God's warning against fleeing to Egypt in Jeremiah 42?
options: The sovereignty of God over nations and judgment on disobedience
The inevitability of earthly success for the faithful
The neutrality of foreign lands in spiritual matters
The superiority of Egyptian gods
questions.correctAnswer: The sovereignty of God over nations and judgment on disobedience
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:15-22 emphasizes God's sovereign control and judgment on those who disobey by fleeing Egypt, consistent with biblical teaching on God's authority over all nations (Psalm 22:28, Daniel 4:35, Romans 13:1, Isaiah 10:5-7).

questions.question: How long did Jeremiah wait before receiving the word of the LORD after the people's request?
options: Ten days
One day
Seven days
Thirty days
questions.correctAnswer: Ten days
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:7 states that the word of the LORD came after ten days, illustrating the often patient waiting period for divine revelation (Exodus 24:16, 1 Samuel 1:19, Acts 1:3, Habakkuk 2:3).

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the final judgment pronounced on those who disobeyed and went to Egypt?
options: Death by sword, famine, and pestilence with no survivors
Prosperity and peace in Egypt
Return to Jerusalem with honor
Becoming priests in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Death by sword, famine, and pestilence with no survivors
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 42:17 and 42:22 declare the comprehensive judgment of death by sword, famine, and pestilence with no escape, consistent with biblical warnings about rejecting God's commands (Deuteronomy 28:64-68, Ezekiel 5:12, Revelation 6:8, Hebrews 10:26-31).
